what: Conduct an AMOC hypothesis test — amoc_test
title: Conduct an AMOC hypothesis test — amoc_test
text: Conduct -one changepoint hypothesis test changes covariance operator functional data based FKWC (functional Kruskal–Wallis covariance changepoint) procedures outlined Ramsay Chenouri (2025).

title: Conduct an AMOC hypothesis test — amoc_test
code: amoc_test(data, ranks = NULL, depth = c("RPD", "FM", "LTR", "FMd", "RPDd"))

title: Conduct an AMOC hypothesis test — amoc_test
text: data Data matrix data.frame form, row observation column dimension. ranks Optional data already ranked. depth Depth function choice.

title: Conduct an AMOC hypothesis test — amoc_test
text: list consisting : $changepoint : Index estimated changepoint. $pvalue : p-value based null distribution. $ranks : vector depth-based ranks observation. $method : string "AMOC test (KWCChangepoint)"

title: Conduct an AMOC hypothesis test — amoc_test
text: options depth argument follows: RPD: Random projection depth FM: Frainman-Muniz depth LTR: \(L^2\)-root depth, suitable detecting changes norm FMd: Frainman-Muniz depth data first order derivative RPDd: Random projection depth data first order derivative depth arguments incorporate first order derivative (approximated using fda.usc::fdata.deriv) result robust detection changes covariance structure (Ramsay Chenouri, 2025).

title: Conduct an AMOC hypothesis test — amoc_test
text: Ramsay, K., & Chenouri, S. (2025). Robust changepoint detection variability multivariate functional data. Journal Nonparametric Statistics. https://doi.org/10.1080/10485252.2025.2503891

title: Conduct an AMOC hypothesis test — amoc_test

what: Find changepoints using depth-based wild binary segmentation — dwbs
title: Find changepoints using depth-based wild binary segmentation — dwbs
text: Detect multiple changepoints multivariate data using depth-based wild binary segmentation algorithm (Ramsay Chenouri, 2023).

title: Find changepoints using depth-based wild binary segmentation — dwbs
code: dwbs(   data,   numInt = 10,   thresh = 1.3584,   alpha = 1,   depth = c("spat", "hs", "mahal", "mahal75") )

title: Find changepoints using depth-based wild binary segmentation — dwbs
text: data Data matrix data.frame form, row observation column dimension. numInt Number intervals generated. thresh Numeric scalar; detection threshold. Larger values make detection conservative. alpha Set 1 default, applying standard SIC penalty. Set number larger 1 strengthened SIC. depth Depth function.

title: Find changepoints using depth-based wild binary segmentation — dwbs
text: list consisting : $changepoints : Indicies change-points detected; return integer(0) change-points detected. $method : string "DWBS"

title: Find changepoints using depth-based wild binary segmentation — dwbs
text: options depth argument follows: spat: Spatial depth hs: Halfspace depth mahal: Mahalanobis depth mahal75: Mahalanobis depth based re-weighted Minimum Covariance Determinant 25% breakdown.

title: Find changepoints using depth-based wild binary segmentation — dwbs
text: Fryzlewicz, Piotr. “Wild Binary Segmentation Multiple Change-Point Detection.” Annals Statistics 42, . 6 (2014). https://doi.org/10.1214/14-AOS1245. Killick, R., P. Fearnhead, . . Eckley. “Optimal Detection Changepoints Linear Computational Cost.” Journal American Statistical Association 107, . 500 (2012): 1590–98. https://doi.org/10.1080/01621459.2012.737745. Ramsay, K., & Chenouri, S. (2023). Robust nonparametric multiple changepoint detection multivariate variability. Econometrics Statistics. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ecosta.2023.09.001

title: Find changepoints using depth-based wild binary segmentation — dwbs
code: set.seed(11) exdata <- rbind(replicate(3,rnorm(200)),                 replicate(3,rnorm(200,10)),                 replicate(3,rnorm(200,0.2))) dwbs(data = exdata) #> $changepoints #> [1] 200 403 #>  #> $method #> [1] "DWBS" #>   # Increasing `numInt` will result in more accurate detection dwbs(data = exdata, numInt = 100) #> $changepoints #> [1] 200 398 #>  #> $method #> [1] "DWBS" #>

what: Detect changepoints in functional data — fkwc
title: Detect changepoints in functional data — fkwc
text: specifically, fkwc() uses functional Kruskal-Wallis tests covariance changepoint algorithm (FKWC) detect changes covariance operator.

title: Detect changepoints in functional data — fkwc
code: fkwc(data, depth = c("RPD", "FM", "LTR", "FMd", "RPDd"), k = 0.25)

title: Detect changepoints in functional data — fkwc
text: data Functional data matrix data.frame form, row observation/function columns grid. depth Depth function choice. k Penalty constant passed pruned exact linear time algorithm.

title: Detect changepoints in functional data — fkwc
text: list consisting : $changepoints : Indices changepoints detected; return integer(0) changepoints detected. $ranks : vector depth-based ranks observation. $method : string "FKWC"

title: Detect changepoints in functional data — fkwc
text: options depth argument follows: RPD: Random projection depth, generally performs best FM: Frainman-Muniz depth LTR: \(L^2\)-root depth, suitable detecting changes norm FMd: Frainman-Muniz depth data first order derivative RPDd: Random projection depth data first order derivative depth arguments incorporate first order derivative (approximated using fda.usc::fdata.deriv) result robust detection changes covariance structure (Ramsay Chenouri, 2025). penalty form $$3.74 + k\sqrt{n}$$ \(n\) number observations. case potentially correlated observations, parameter set \(k=1\). information found reference.

title: Detect changepoints in functional data — fkwc
text: Killick, R., P. Fearnhead, . . Eckley. “Optimal Detection Changepoints Linear Computational Cost.” Journal American Statistical Association 107, . 500 (2012): 1590–98. https://doi.org/10.1080/01621459.2012.737745. Ramsay, K., & Chenouri, S. (2025). Robust changepoint detection variability multivariate functional data. Journal Nonparametric Statistics. https://doi.org/10.1080/10485252.2025.2503891

title: Detect changepoints in functional data — fkwc
code: set.seed(2) # Generating 80 observations, with a changepoint (in our case a change in # kernel) at observation 40 n  <- 80 k0 <- 40 T  <- 30 t  <- seq(0, 1, length.out = T)   # Both kernels K1 and K2 are Gaussian (or squared exponential) kernels but # with different lengthscale values, and thus we hope to detect it. K_se <- function(s, t, ell) exp(- ( (s - t)^2 ) / (2 * ell^2)) K1   <- outer(t, t, function(a,b) K_se(a,b, ell = 0.20)) K2   <- outer(t, t, function(a,b) K_se(a,b, ell = 0.07))  L1 <- chol(K1 + 1e-8 * diag(T)) L2 <- chol(K2 + 1e-8 * diag(T))  Z1 <- matrix(rnorm(k0 * T),      k0,      T) Z2 <- matrix(rnorm((n-k0) * T),  n - k0,  T)  # We finally have an 80 x 30 matrix where the rows are the observations and # the columns are the grid points. X  <- rbind(Z1 %*% t(L1), Z2 %*% t(L2))  fkwc(X) #> $changepoints #> [1] 19 40 #>  #> $ranks #>  [1] 50 19 10 14 56 21 76 47 80 35 62 17 53 18 15  6  2 43 26 67 58 64 66 61 48 #> [26] 60 72 39 75 22 65  8 68  1 74 70 77 59 78 51 13 38 24 27 63 55  4 12 42 79 #> [51]  3 29 34 52 37 11  7 31 32 23 25 57 28 71 36 40 46 54 73 44 33  9  5 16 69 #> [76] 45 30 41 49 20 #>  #> $method #> [1] "FKWC" #>

what: Multisample hypothesis test for difference in covariance operators — fkwc_multisample
title: Multisample hypothesis test for difference in covariance operators — fkwc_multisample
text: Executes multisample hypothesis test differences covariance operators using functional Kruskal–Wallis tests covariance (FKWC) outlined Ramsay Chenouri (2024). function requires first order derivative functional data order better detect changes.

title: Multisample hypothesis test for difference in covariance operators — fkwc_multisample
code: fkwc_multisample(data, derivs, g, p = 20)

title: Multisample hypothesis test for difference in covariance operators — fkwc_multisample
text: data Functional data matrix data.frame form, row observation/function columns grid. derivs First order derivative functional data matrix data.frame form. g factor object indicates sample row data belongs . p Number random projections generated order compute random projection depths data.

title: Multisample hypothesis test for difference in covariance operators — fkwc_multisample
text: list consisting : $statistic : observed test statistic. $pvalue : p-value based null distribution. $method : string "FKWC"

title: Multisample hypothesis test for difference in covariance operators — fkwc_multisample
text: Ramsay, K., & Chenouri, S. (2024). Robust nonparametric hypothesis tests differences covariance structure functional data. Canadian Journal Statistics, 52 (1), 43–78. https://doi.org/10.1002/cjs.11767

title: Multisample hypothesis test for difference in covariance operators — fkwc_multisample
code: set.seed(111) t <- seq(0, 1, length.out = 200)  ### Generating three sets of Brownian curves with different kernels, each ### kernel generating 20 observations # Brownian process 1 fd1 <- fda.usc::rproc2fdata(n = 20, t = t, sigma = "brownian",                            par.list = list(scale = 10, theta = 1)) fd1_d <- fda.usc::fdata.deriv(fd1)  # Brownian process 2 fd2 <- fda.usc::rproc2fdata(n = 20, t = t, sigma = "brownian",                            par.list = list(scale = 1, theta = 1)) fd2_d <- fda.usc::fdata.deriv(fd2)  # Brownian process 3 fd3 <- fda.usc::rproc2fdata(n = 20, t = t, sigma = "brownian",                            par.list = list(scale = 1, theta = 5)) fd3_d <- fda.usc::fdata.deriv(fd3)  # Functional data in one matrix and first order derivatives in another matrix funcdata <- rbind(fd1$data, fd2$data, fd3$data) funcderivs <- rbind(fd1_d$data, fd2_d$data, fd3_d$data)  fkwc_multisample(data = funcdata,                  derivs = funcderivs,                  g = factor(rep(1:3, each = 20)),                  p = 1000) #> $statistic #> [1] 38.56262 #>  #> $pvalue #> [1] 4.228953e-09 #>  #> $method #> [1] "FKWC multi-sample hypothesis test" #>

what: Post-hoc hypothesis test for difference in covariance operators. — fkwc_posthoc

title: Post-hoc hypothesis test for difference in covariance operators. — fkwc_posthoc

title: Post-hoc hypothesis test for difference in covariance operators. — fkwc_posthoc
text: data Functional data matrix data.frame form, row observation/function columns grid. derivs First order derivative functional data matrix data.frame form. g factor object indicates sample row data belongs . p Number random projections generated order compute random projection depths data.

title: Post-hoc hypothesis test for difference in covariance operators. — fkwc_posthoc
text: matrix p-values pairwise comparison Šidák correction applied.

title: Post-hoc hypothesis test for difference in covariance operators. — fkwc_posthoc
text: Ramsay, K., & Chenouri, S. (2024). Robust nonparametric hypothesis tests differences covariance structure functional data. Canadian Journal Statistics, 52 (1), 43–78. https://doi.org/10.1002/cjs.11767

title: Post-hoc hypothesis test for difference in covariance operators. — fkwc_posthoc
code: set.seed(111) t <- seq(0, 1, length.out = 200)  ### Generating three sets of brownian curves with different kernels # Brownian process 1 fd1 <- fda.usc::rproc2fdata(n = 20, t = t, sigma = "brownian",                            par.list = list(scale = 10, theta = 1)) fd1_d <- fda.usc::fdata.deriv(fd1)  # Brownian process 2 fd2 <- fda.usc::rproc2fdata(n = 20, t = t, sigma = "brownian",                            par.list = list(scale = 1, theta = 1)) fd2_d <- fda.usc::fdata.deriv(fd2)  # Brownian process 3 fd3 <- fda.usc::rproc2fdata(n = 20, t = t, sigma = "brownian",                            par.list = list(scale = 1, theta = 5)) fd3_d <- fda.usc::fdata.deriv(fd3)  # Functional data in one matrix and first order derivatives in another matrix funcdata <- rbind(fd1$data, fd2$data, fd3$data) funcderivs <- rbind(fd1_d$data, fd2_d$data, fd3_d$data)  fkwc_posthoc(data = funcdata,              derivs = funcderivs,              g = factor(rep(1:3, each = 20)),              p = 1000) #>              1            2            3 #> 1           NA 3.439663e-07 2.198030e-07 #> 2 3.439663e-07           NA 9.999899e-01 #> 3 2.198030e-07 9.999899e-01           NA

what: KWCChangepoint: Robust Changepoint Detection for Functional and Multivariate Data — KWCChangepoint-package
title: KWCChangepoint: Robust Changepoint Detection for Functional and Multivariate Data — KWCChangepoint-package
text: Detect test changes covariance structures functional data, well changepoint detection multivariate data generally. Method detecting non-stationarity resting state functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI) scans seen Ramsay, K., & Chenouri, S. (2025) doi:10.1080/10485252.2025.2503891  implemented fmri_changepoints(). Also includes depth- rank-based implementation wild binary segmentation algorithm detecting multiple changepoints multivariate data.

what: Find changepoints in multivariate data — mkwp
title: Find changepoints in multivariate data — mkwp
text: mkwp() function detects changepoints multivariate data using multivariate Kruskal-Wallis PELT (MKWP) algorithm developed Ramsay Chenouri (2023).

title: Find changepoints in multivariate data — mkwp
code: mkwp(data, depth = c("spat", "mahal", "mahal75", "hs"), k = 0.2)

title: Find changepoints in multivariate data — mkwp
text: data Data matrix data.frame form, row observation column dimension. depth Depth function. k Penalty constant passed pruned exact linear time algorithm.

title: Find changepoints in multivariate data — mkwp
text: list consisting : $changepoints : Indices changepoints detected; return integer(0) changepoints detected. $method : string "Multivariate Kruskal-Wallis PELT (MKWP)"

title: Find changepoints in multivariate data — mkwp
text: options depth argument follows: spat: Spatial depth hs: Halfspace depth mahal: Mahalanobis depth mahal75: Mahalanobis depth based re-weighted Minimum Covariance Determinant 25% breakdown. Spatial depth default choice, computationally quicker depths larger data giving similar result depths. penalty form $$3.74 + k\sqrt{n}$$ \(n\) number observations. case potentially correlated observations, parameter set \(k=1\). information found reference.

title: Find changepoints in multivariate data — mkwp
text: Killick, R., P. Fearnhead, . . Eckley. “Optimal Detection Changepoints Linear Computational Cost.” Journal American Statistical Association 107, . 500 (2012): 1590–98. https://doi.org/10.1080/01621459.2012.737745. Ramsay, K., & Chenouri, S. (2023). Robust nonparametric multiple changepoint detection multivariate variability. Econometrics Statistics. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ecosta.2023.09.001

title: Find changepoints in multivariate data — mkwp
code: set.seed(111) multi_data <-rbind(replicate(3,rnorm(200)),                    replicate(3,rnorm(200,10)),                    replicate(3,rnorm(200,0.2))) mkwp(multi_data) #> $changepoints #> [1] 201 398 #>  #> $method #> [1] "Multivariate Kruskal-Wallis PELT (MKWP)" #>

what: Detect changepoints in a resting state fMRI scan — fmri_changepoints
title: Detect changepoints in a resting state fMRI scan — fmri_changepoints
text: Functional magnetic resonance imaging scans expected stationary pre-processed. function attempts find potential changepoints using findings Ramsay Chenouri (2025).

title: Detect changepoints in a resting state fMRI scan — fmri_changepoints
code: fmri_changepoints(data, p = 100, k = 0.3)

title: Detect changepoints in a resting state fMRI scan — fmri_changepoints
text: data four dimensional array, fourth dimension time. p Number random vector projections, set 100 default. k Penalty constant passed pruned exact linear time algorithm.

title: Detect changepoints in a resting state fMRI scan — fmri_changepoints
text: list consisting : $changepoints : Indices change-points detected; return integer(0) changepoints detected. $ranks : vector depth-based ranks time stamp. $method : string "fMRI changepoints (KWCChangepoint)"

title: Detect changepoints in a resting state fMRI scan — fmri_changepoints
text: penalty form $$3.74 + k\sqrt{n}$$ \(n\) number observations. case potentially correlated observations, parameter set \(k=1\). information found reference. example document simple "toy example", good fMRI data simulation requires dependencies. generating fMRI data, see neuRosim::simVOLfmri(), neuRosim::simTSrestingstate().

title: Detect changepoints in a resting state fMRI scan — fmri_changepoints
text: Ramsay, K., & Chenouri, S. (2025). Robust changepoint detection variability multivariate functional data. Journal Nonparametric Statistics. https://doi.org/10.1080/10485252.2025.2503891

title: Detect changepoints in a resting state fMRI scan — fmri_changepoints
code: # In order to replicate how a changepoint would appear in a resting-state # fMRI scan in a manner that is not computationally expensive, this example # constructs an image of a 3D ball taken at 12 time stamps. The noise, and # therefore the covariance function, changes at time stamp 6. x_dim <- 24 y_dim <- 24 z_dim <- 10 time_dim <- 12 image_array <- array(0, dim = c(x_dim, y_dim, z_dim, time_dim))  center <- c(x_dim / 2, y_dim / 2, z_dim / 2) radius <- min(x_dim, y_dim, z_dim) / 4  set.seed(42)  for (t in 1:time_dim) {   for (x in 1:x_dim) {     for (y in 1:y_dim) {       for (z in 1:z_dim) {         dist_from_center <- sqrt((x - center[1])^2 + (y - center[2])^2 + (z - center[3])^2)         if (dist_from_center <= radius) {           # Adding noise with increasing variability at timestamp 6           if (t <= 6) {             noise <- rnorm(1, mean = 0, sd = 0.1)  # Low variability noise           } else {             noise <- rnorm(1, mean = 0, sd = 2)  # High variability noise           }           image_array[x, y, z, t] <- noise         } else {           # Add lower intensity noise outside the ball           image_array[x, y, z, t] <- rnorm(1, mean = 0, sd = 0.005)         }       }     }   } } fmri_changepoints(image_array, k = 0.1, p = 10) #> Warning: executing %dopar% sequentially: no parallel backend registered #> $changepoints #> [1] 6 #>  #> $ranks #>  [1]  7 12  8  9 10 11  4  3  5  6  2  1 #>  #> $method #> [1] "fMRI changepoints (KWCChangepoint)" #>

what: Find mean changes in a univariate sequence — uni_mean
title: Find mean changes in a univariate sequence — uni_mean
text: uni_mean() function ranks observations smallest largest, applies pruned exact linear time algorithm penalty parameter beta detect changepoints.

title: Find mean changes in a univariate sequence — uni_mean
code: uni_mean(data, beta = 10)

title: Find mean changes in a univariate sequence — uni_mean
text: data vector one-dimensional array. beta Numeric penalty constant passed pruned exact linear time algorithm.

title: Find mean changes in a univariate sequence — uni_mean
text: list consisting : $changepoints : Indices changepoints detected; return integer(0) changepoints detected. $method : string "Univariate Changepoint Mean (FKWC)"

title: Find mean changes in a univariate sequence — uni_mean
text: Killick, R., P. Fearnhead, . . Eckley. “Optimal Detection Changepoints Linear Computational Cost.” Journal American Statistical Association 107, . 500 (2012): 1590–98. https://doi.org/10.1080/01621459.2012.737745.

title: Find mean changes in a univariate sequence — uni_mean
code: set.seed(11) mean_test <- c(rnorm(100, mean = 0), # before change in mean                rnorm(100, mean = 5)) # after change in mean uni_mean(mean_test) #> $changepoints #> [1] 100 #>  #> $method #> [1] "Univariate Changepoint in Mean (KWCChangepoint)" #>

title: Find scale changes in a univariate sequence — uni_scale
code: set.seed(11) scale_test <- c(rnorm(100, sd=5), # before change in sale                 rnorm(100, sd=1)) # after change in scale uni_scale(scale_test) #> $changepoints #> [1] 100 #>  #> $method #> [1] "Univariate Changepoint in Scale (KWCChangepoint)" #>
